content.user_title: Generate Modern CSS with shadcn Aesthetic
content.value_statement: Stop writing old-school CSS with hard-coded colors and random values. This skill teaches Claude to generate modern, accessible CSS using shadcn/ui design principles with CSS variables, HSL colors, and consistent spacing.
actual_capabilities: Generates modern CSS with CSS variables for complete theming
Uses HSL color system with opacity support
Implements proper focus-visible states for accessibility
limitations: Only provides CSS/SCSS styling patterns, no component logic
Requires manual implementation of CSS variables in your project
Designed specifically for shadcn/ui aesthetic, may not suit all design needs

best_practices: Always use CSS variables for colors to enable complete theming
Apply consistent spacing scale based on 4px increments for visual harmony
Implement focus-visible states for better keyboard navigation accessibility
anti_patterns: Avoid hard-coding hex colors that cannot be themed
Do not use random pixel values that break visual consistency
Never remove focus outlines without providing focus-visible alternatives

faq.question: Does this work with my existing CSS framework?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns are framework-agnostic and work alongside Tailwind, Bootstrap, or vanilla CSS projects.

faq.question: How do I implement dark mode?
faq.answer: Simply add a 'dark' class to your HTML element and all colors automatically switch to dark mode variants.

faq.question: Can I customize the color scheme?
faq.answer: Yes, modify the HSL values in the CSS variables to match your brand colors while maintaining the same patterns.

faq.question: Is this compatible with SCSS/Sass?
faq.answer: Absolutely, all patterns work in SCSS and can be extended with mixins and functions.

faq.question: Does it support older browsers?
faq.answer: The patterns use modern CSS features. For older browsers, you may need to provide fallbacks for CSS variables.

faq.question: How does this compare to Tailwind?
faq.answer: This provides semantic CSS patterns rather than utility classes, giving you more control over component styling.
